topic.title: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade 2.0 Alpha: Installing the KVM Deployment

body.p: After the Helion Lifecycle Management (HLM) is installed, the next task in installing the KVM deployment is to deploy the HP Helion Openstack cloud.
Note: If you are installing the KVM + ESX deployment, see Installing the KVM + ESX Deployment.

section.title: Log into the HLM VM
section.p: Log into the HLM VM you created in the previous page.

ol.li:
Login to HLM VM. ssh <HLM_VM_IP> where: HLM_VM_IP is the CLM IP of the HLM VM.
Use the cghelion credentials: User Name: cghelion Password: cghelion
Important: After logging in with the default password, make sure you change the password for the cghelion user.
Execute the following command to switch to the root user:sudo su -
On the HLM VM, change to the home directory.cd ~

Provision and configure your HP Helion OpenStack VM.hnewcloud <cloudname> denver
Where:
<cloudname> is the name of the cloud to create:
The cloud name can be any combination of up to 63 digits, letters, and the - chracter:
Cannot start or end with the - chracter;
Must be greater than 0 characters;
No restriction on the number of letters or digits (0 or more).
denver is the name of the template to use. The installation kit includes the denver template.
The command creates the <cloudname> directory, which will contain a JSON template file node-provision.json. This template supplies input values to the hprovision script, later in the installation.

The HP Helion OpenStack deployment requires a JSON file. Edit node-provision.json file to change only the following fields:
Field Description
Pxe-mac-address MAC address of the interface you want to PXE boot onto. This is not same as iLO MAC address.
pm_ip Power management IP (iLO ip)
pm_user Power management user (iLO username)
pm_pass Power management password (iLO password)
failure_zone, vendor, model, os_partition_size, data_partition_size Enter the same value as for these fields an in the nodes.json file used during cloud deployment
To see a sample node-provision.json file, seeSample JSON File for the HLM Virtual Machine Installation.

section.title: Verify the JSON files
section.p: After editing the JSON files, validate each JSON file to make sure there are no syntax errors using the tool of your preference. For example, using the Python json.tool:

section.title: Configure PXE boot
section.p: After you edit the node-provision.json file, you must enable one-time PXE boot on the servers set the correct boot order. Execute the following on the HLM VM:

ol.li: Copy the ilopxebootonce.py from the /root/cg-hlm/dev-tools/ilopxebootonce.py to the directory where you have the node-provision.json file.
Execute the following script: python ilopxebootonce.py node-provision.json

section.p: After the script is run, the Current One-Time Boot Option is set to Network Device 1 on all the servers listed in node-provision.json file.

ol.li:
Use the following script to start the provisioning of the HP Helion OpenStack cloud: hprovision <cloudname>
Where:
<cloudname> is the name of the cloud to create
This script will PXE boot the nodes specified in node-provision.json file. The script also tracks the PXE boot completion process and will create the nodes.json file in the directory.

Make sure the nodes are booted up.
a. Change to the <cloudname> directory:cd ~/<cloudname>
b. Once the baremetal nodes are provisioned, make sure the nodes.json file is generated and that you can establish a password-less SSH connection to these nodes from HLM VM.

Configure the back-end drivers to enable management of the OpenStack Block Storage volumes in the KVM region equipped with 3PAR and/or VSA storage arrays. The HP Block Storage (Cinder) service allows you to configure multiple storage back-ends. Use the following steps to configure back-end support:
Change to the cinder/blocks directory: cd ~/<cloudname>/services/cinder/blocks Where <cloudname> is the name you assigned to the cloud. The directory contains several sample Cinder configuration files that you can edit, depending upon which storage method(s) you are using.
Depending upon they type of storage you are using, edit one of the following files:
3PAR - if you plan to have only HP StoreServ (3PAR) storage attached to the KVM region, edit the cinder_conf.hp3parSample file.
VSA - if you plan to have only HP StoreVirtual VSA storage attached to the KVM region, edit the cinder_conf.vsasample file.
3PAR and VSA - if you plan to have HP StoreServ (3PAR) and HP StoreVirtual VSA storage attached to the KVM region, edit the cinder_conf.multiBackendSample file, which contains variables for both storage types.
Use the enabled_backends variable to list each of the back-ends you are using. You must specify at least one back-end for the KVM region.
Region/Hypervisor Volume Backend Backend Name
KVM 3PAR hp3par
KVM VSA hplefthand
Note: You can use either 3PAR and VSA in the KVM region or select both if you have respective storage arrays
For 3PAR storage : Edit the cinder_conf.hp3parSample file to configure the 3PAR settings. For example:[DEFAULT] enabled_backends=hp3par
[hp3par] volume_backend_name=<mybackendname1> hp3par_api_url=https://<management_ip>:8080/api/v1 hp3par_username=<username> hp3par_password=<password> hp3par_cpg=<cpg> san_ip=<san_ip> san_login=<username> san_password=<password> hp3par_iscsi_ips=<iscsi_target_ips seperated by ,> volume_driver=cinder.volume.drivers.san.hp.hp_3par_iscsi.HP3PARISCSIDriver hp3par_debug=False hp3par_iscsi_chap_enabled=false hp3par_snapshot_retention=48 hp3par_snapshot_expiration=72
VSA storage: Edit the cinder_conf.vsasample file to configure the VSA settings. For example: [DEFAULT] enabled_backends=hplefthand
[hplefthand] volume_backend_name=<mybackendname2> hplefthand_username = <username> hplefthand_password = <password> hplefthand_clustername = <Cluster Name> hplefthand_api_url = https://<Iscsi Virtual IP address>/lhos
3PAR and VSA storage: If you are using both 3par and VSA, the configuration should look like:
[DEFAULT] enabled_backends=hp3par, hplefthand [hp3par] volume_backend_name=<mybackendname1> hp3par_api_url=https://<management_ip>:8080/api/v1 hp3par_username=<username> hp3par_password=<password> hp3par_cpg=<cpg> san_ip=<san_ip> san_login=<username> san_password=<password> hp3par_iscsi_ips=<iscsi_target_ips seperated by ,> volume_driver=cinder.volume.drivers.san.hp.hp_3par_iscsi.HP3PARISCSIDriver hp3par_debug=False hp3par_iscsi_chap_enabled=false hp3par_snapshot_retention=48 hp3par_snapshot_expiration=72
[hplefthand] volume_backend_name=<mybackendname2> hplefthand_username = <username> hplefthand_password = <password> hplefthand_clustername = <Cluster Name> hplefthand_api_url = https://<Iscsi Virtual IP address>/lhos
Save the file to cinder_conf.

section.title: Deploy the Configuration Processor Patches
section.p: Before launching the HP Helion OpenStack cloud in the following section, deploy two patches to update required configuration files.
See the README in the download or Deploying the Configuration Processor Patches.

section.title: Deploy the HP Helion OpenStack cloud

ol.li:
Once you have correctly edited all the json files and applied the appropriate patches, run the HP Helion OpenStack Configuration Processor: hcfgproc -d definition.json
The HP Helion OpenStack Configuration Processor is a script, called hcfgproc, that is incorporated into the installation environment.
Review the CloudDiagram, hosts.hf, and net/interfaces.d/eth.cfg files to make sure the network settings are correct.

Initialize network interfaces on all the cloud nodes using the following command: hnetinit <cloudname>
You can run this command from any directory.
After this command completes, all cloud nodes and CLM network interfaces should be set correctly.

Use the following command to deploy the cloud: hdeploy <cloudname>
Once cloud deployment is successfully complete, there will be 3 controller nodes in the non-KVM region.

body.section:
Deploy the Role Generator PatchesAfter launching the hdeploy command, deploy two following patches to correct the following issues:
The floating IP assigned to the HLM VM not pingable with DCNR3 and VSD managed networks.
The installation fails due to excessive ESX logs
For information, see Deploying the Role Generator Patches.

section.title: Configure LDAP to enable CLI and use Keystone v3
section.p: By default, the HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade services are configured to use Keystone v2 authorization. The services need to be modified to use Keystone v3. Users will not be able to execute OpenStack CLI commands until the specific changes are made on all three controller nodes in the non-KVM region.
For information, see Configuring LDAP CLI Support

section.title: Disable the Root User
section.p: For security purposes, we strongly recommend disabling root. After the root user is disabled, you can use another default user account, cghelion to access the HLM VM and any actions that require root access should be done using sudo.
For more information, see Disabling the Root User.
